data.text:
"Writing Tools" by Roy Peter Clark

There are not many good books on writing music. Plenty of writers have tried, but almost every one I've read has left me unsatisfied. There are, however, a lot of good books on writing words, and there are so many parallels to writing music that they are worth reading as a composer."Writing Tools" by Roy Peter Clark is one such book. It offers 50 short tips for writing, and I've found that maybe 3/4 of them can be translated to music. I will most likely develop many of these into their own posts, so for now I'll just list the relevant tools and my brief translation from writing to composing.

Begin sentences with subjects and verbs - Start with strong and interesting motives

Activate your verbs - Activate your melodies with runs, trills, and other flourishes

Fear not the long sentence - Fear not the long phrase, especially one that builds and rises in tension and suspense

Establish a pattern, then give it a twist

Let punctuation control pace and space - Let cadences control pace

Prefer the simple over the technical - Don't over-busy things so they become unclear

Give key words their space - Use rests

Get the name of the dog - Work down to every detail

Seek original images - Seek original figures, cadences, sounds, etc.

Riff on the creative language of others - Riff on the harmony, phrases, orchestration, etc. of others

Set the pace with sentence length - Set the pace with phrase length and harmonic rhythm

Vary the lengths of paragraphs - Vary the lengths of phrases and sections

Know when to back off and when to show off - The more serious the subject the more restrained you should be

Tune your voice - Be authentic in your writing

Work from a plan - Sketch out the basic form first

Learn the difference between reports and stories - Scoring what is on screen vs what it means for the story

Use dialogue as a form of action - Get energy from the line, not just ostinato and rhythmic parts

Put odd and interesting things next to each other - Make liberal use of contrast

Foreshadow dramatic events and powerful conclusions - Tie every element together with a common motivic thread

To generate suspense, use internal cliffhangers - Use half cadences to keep things moving forward

Build your work around a key question - Build your piece around a central motive

Place gold coins along the path - Use the 7-8 moments idea to keep interesting nuggets throughout your piece

Repeat, repeat, and repeat- Do not be afraid to be repetitive if you are using variation

Write from different cinematic angles - Make good use of contrasting dynamics

Report and write for scenes - Write section by section

Prefer archetypes to stereotypes - Don't use cliches, but use the effects they produce

Write toward an ending - Write phrases with a destination in mind, otherwise you're just rambling

Draft a missing statement for your work

Read for both form and content - Listen for both form and content

Save string - Save your ideas, don't delete if you don't have to

Break long projects into parts

Take an interest in all crafts that support your work

Recruit your own support group

Limited self-criticism in early drafts - Write first, edit later

Learn from your critics

Own the tools of your craft

Are you interested in studying music with a professional composer? I now offer private instruction via Skype in composition, harmony, orchestration and music production. Visit my lessons page for more information!
